Award.AwardTitle: Ph.D. Forum at the International Conference on Parallel Processing (ICPP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Now in its 47th year, the International Conference on Parallel Processing (ICPP) is one of the longest continuously running conferences in parallel processing, and it is a rewarding event for Ph.D. graduate students to connect with and learn from the parallel computing community. The Ph.D. Forum at ICPP promotes the progress of science as stated by NSF's mission by creating a rich educational and learning experience where Ph.D. graduate students (i) present and discuss their research in parallel computing with conference attendees, (ii) expand their understanding of the parallel computing by attending technical sessions, (iii) explore potential research projects with new colleagues, and (iv) receive guidance from leaders in the field. By assisting in the training, development, and mentorship of the next-generation of parallel computing researchers, the ICPP Ph.D. Forum is contributing to the NSF's mission for advancements in science, support for education and diversity, and broader benefits to society.

This award will support the travel of up to 24 eligible students from US-based institutions to participate in the student program at ICPP 2018 and to organize a PhD Forum. There are two main objectives of the Ph.D. Forum at ICPP. First, it provides Ph.D. students with intellectual opportunities to discuss their research work in a constructive and supportive environment where leading parallel computing topics are presented and debated. Second, it provides mentoring resources to help graduate students organize their academic research work and plan for their future careers. The Ph.D. Forum makes it possible for graduate students to (i) present their research during the poster session, (ii) give a 2-3 minute introduction during a Ph.D. mentor luncheon, (iii) attend a special parallel computing career session, (iv) meet and interact with designated faculty and industry mentors during the conference, and (v) distribute their research materials (poster, abstract) and CV to other ICPP participants. A Ph.D. Forum award acknowledges best overall poster, introduction, and participation. An associated objective is to lay the groundwork for continuation of the Ph.D. Forum in future years of ICPP. For this purpose, Ph.D. students provide feedback on their experience at ICPP and thoughts for improvements in the Ph.D. Forum.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Conference on Parallel Processing (ICPP) is one of the longest continuously running conferences in parallel processing.  The 47th ICPP meeting was held in Eugene, Oregon at the University of Oregon from August 13-16, 2018.  ICPP is a forum for scientists and engineers in academia, industry, and government to present their latest research findings.  It is also an important event for Ph.D. graduate students to connect with and learn from the parallel computing community.  ICPP 2018 revived the long-time tradition of engaging with Ph.D. students during the conference.  While in the past this was more informal, a more structured Ph.D. Forum was created for the first time in ICPP's history.

The Ph.D. Forum at ICPP promoted the progress of science as stated by NSF's mission by creating a rich educational and learning experience where Ph.D. graduate students (i) present and discuss their research in parallel computing with conference attendees, (ii) expand their understanding of the parallel computing by attending technical sessions, (iii) explore potential research projects with new colleagues, and (iv) receive guidance from leaders in the field.  For these reasons, NSF funding was requested to make it possible for the Ph.D. graduate students to attend.  By assisting in the training, development, and mentorship of the next-generation of parallel computing researchers, the ICPP Ph.D. Forum contributed to the NSF's mission for advancements in science, support for education and diversity, and broader benefits to society.

Overall, ICPP was extremely successful, with a significant increases in the number of papers submitted/accepted and the number of attendees.  The Ph.D. Forum was well-received and highly-appreciated by the participants.  There were 25 Ph.D. students who participated, the majority of which came from U.S. academic institutions.  They are listed below:

  Vignesh Adhinarayanan, Virginia Tech, USA
  Xinyu Chen, University of New Mexico, USA
  Hoang-Vu Dang, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, USA
  Sajal Dash, Virginia Tech, USA
  Jose Manuel Monsalve Diaz, University of Delaware, USA
  Alvaro Fernandez, Universidad de Valencie, Spain
  Jason Hiebel, Michigan Technological University, USA
  Saurabh Kalikar, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, India
  Anuva Kulkarni, Carnegie Mellon University, USA
  Robert Lim, University of Oregon, USA
  Mohammad Alaul Haque Monil, University of Oregon, USA
  Payal Nandy, University of Utah, USA
  Ioannis Paraskevakos, Rutgers University, USA
  Anmol Paudel Marquette, University, USA
  Tiago Barreto Perez, University of Colorado, Colorado Springs, USA
  Sarunya Pumma, Virginia Tech, USA
  Md Shafayat Rahman, Florida State University, USA
  Sunimal Rathnayake, National University of Singapore, Singapore
  Suleyman Savas, Halmstad University, Sweden
  Shehenaz Shaik Auburn, University, USA
  Kanika Sood, University of Oregon, USA
  Xi Wang, Texas Tech University, USA
  Chad Wood, University of Oregon, USA
  Carl Yang, University of California, Davis, USA
  Weidong Zhang, Peking University,China

The University of Oregon Ph.D. students served as Forum cohorts to assist in any logistics and to interact with the other Ph.D. students on local matters.

Three Co-Chairs were recruited to help organize the activities of the Ph.D. Forum.  They represented academia, government labs, and industry research.  In addition to the Co-Chairs, mentors were recruited to participate in the Ph.D. Forum and interact and advise with the students.  The Co-Chairs were chartered with arranging a 2-day schedule for the Ph.D. students that consisted of introduction, invited talk, poster session, mentorship, and career planning.  The Ph.D. Forum posters were presented as part of the ICPP poster session.  It was well attended and all the Ph.D. students received positive feedback from the attendees.
